arm_group.description:
group is assigned to "block 1": shoemaker 1 produces shoes according to standard methods, shoemaker 2 uses plantar pressure measurements.
group is assigned to "standard": wears shoes produced with standard procedure

group is assigned to "block 1": shoemaker 1 produces shoes according to standard methods, shoemaker 2 uses plantar pressure measurements
group is assigned to "with measurements": wears shoes produced with plantar pressure measurements

group is assigned to "block 2": shoemaker 2 produces shoes according to standard methods, shoemaker 1 uses plantar pressure measurements
group is assigned to "standard": wears shoes produced with standard procedure

group assigned to "block 2": shoemaker 2 produces shoes according to standard methods, shoemaker 1 uses plantar pressure measurements
group is assigned to "with measurements": wears shoes produced with plantar pressure measurements

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is determine whether the use of plantar pressure measurements in
      the production of customized therapeutic footwear for patients with diabetes and a history
      of foot ulceration results in lower production costs and more pressure relief, compared to
      the standard production. A secondary objective is to explore if a difference in durability
      can be observed in pressure reduction and development of (pre-) ulcerative lesions between
      the shoes produced with and without plantar pressure measurements.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cost-effectiveness of In-shoe Pressure Measurement for Therapeutic Shoes

detailed_description.textblock:
For each patient two pairs of shoes will be produced by two shoemakers, one using plantar
      pressure measurements and one according current standard production procedures. The patient
      will wear one of these two pairs of shoes during a period of 3 months.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  diabetes

          -  neuropathy

          -  prescription of therapeutic footwear

          -  diabetic foot ulcer in the last 5 years

          -  receiving regular preventive foot care

          -  written informed consent

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  peripheral arterial disease

          -  not motivated to wear therapeutic footwear

          -  active foot ulcer

          -  recent vascular intervention

          -  severe mobility impairment

          -  amputation more proximal than toes, except a single ray amputation is allowed.

          -  severe visual impairment

          -  active cancer

          -  severe cardiac/ pulmonary failure

          -  severe oedema

          -  chronic drug abuse

          -  severe psychiatric illness

          -  hospital admission at the time of inclusion

          -  any condition that may interfere with follow-up visits.

intervention.description: shoemaker 1 produces shoes according to standard methods, shoemaker 2 uses plantar pressure measurements
shoemaker 2 produces shoes according to standard methods, shoemaker 1 uses plantar pressure measurements
patient wears shoes produced with standard method
patient wears shoes produced with plantar pressure measurements

clinical_study.official_title: Improving the Cost-effectiveness of Therapeutic Shoes for Diabetic Patients With a Previous Foot Ulcer Using an In-shoe Pressure Device

authority: Netherlands: The Central Committee on Research Involving Human Subjects (CCMO)

primary_outcome.measure: The cost-effectiveness of shoes produced with and without plantar pressure measurements.
primary_outcome.time_frame: approximately 10 weeks (at delivery of the shoes)

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in plantar pressure after wearing the therapeutic shoes for 3 months.

secondary_outcome.description: The number of diabetic foot problems serves as an additional measure of the quality of the therapeutic shoes produced.
secondary_outcome.measure: The number of participants with reported and/ or visible new diabetic foot problems, such as ulcera or pre-ulcerative lesions.

secondary_outcome.description: Qualitative measure of differences in production process of the shoes produced with or without plantar pressure measurements.
secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in production techniques, materials and procedures used by the two shoemakers to produce the two pair of shoes.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: approximately 10 weeks (at delivery of the shoes)

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in plantar pressures between the two shoes produced.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: approximately 10 weeks (at delivery of the shoes)

secondary_outcome.measure: The use and usability of the shoes produced, measured with the questionnaire "Monitor Orthopaedic Shoes".
Differences in plantar pressures between the two shoes produced.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label
